image.altText: A sign reads 'BEAUMARIS PRIMARY SCHOOL' behind gum leaves.

props.synopsis: A survivor of "shocking" sexual abuse at a Melbourne primary school has received what his lawyer has called "the biggest publicly-known payment to an abuse survivor in Australia" in an extraordinary $8 million settlement with the Victorian Education Department.

title.children: Sexual abuse survivor to receive $8 million in record-breaking settlement

image.altText: Police tape at a crime scene

props.synopsis: Police have shot dead three dogs which attacked a woman at a home in Dandenong in Melbourne's south-east. The woman was left with critical injuries.Â

title.children: Police shoot three dogs dead after attack leaves woman critically injured

image.altText: Four yellow-lidded bins on a street corner, the second from left has its lid open.

props.synopsis: Regional Victorian councils have told two separate inquiries, including a federal one, that they're having to do more with less and that their remit now is much more than just "roads, rates, and rubbish".

title.children: Councils don't have enough money to do everything asked of them. So what's the answer?

image.altText: An illustration of a young person talking to a police officer

props.synopsis: In the midst of a spike in Victorian youth crime, researchers say young people with intellectual disabilities are going unsupported and overlooked in the criminal justice system.

title.children: 'I was just saying yes, yes, yes': Young people with intellectual disabilities over-represented in justice system

image.altText: A young man in a suit with short hair and sculpted facial hair smiles happily for a portrait.

props.synopsis: IBAC investigators say a former mayor of Moonee Valley City Council repeatedly accepted drugs in exchange for progressing property applications.

title.children: 'God status': Mayor repeatedly accepted drugs in exchange for planning help, finds IBAC report

image.altText: Dan Houston applauds Port Adelaide fans

props.synopsis: Port Adelaide star Dan Houston appears to be a step closer to securing his favoured move to a Victorian club. Follow live as we bring you all the action from day four of the AFL trade period.

title.children: Collingwood closes in on Dan Houston move after key meetings as Carlton drops out

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Carlton 'all but ruled out' of Dan Houston race
Giants forward re-signs amid Bombers links
The latest on Jake Stringer and the Giants

image.altText: Young adult woman in black blazer stands in front of garden bed with neutral expression

props.synopsis: Federation University is set to cop the biggest reduction Australia-wide under a proposed cap on international student numbers, with a 52 per cent reduction in new overseas enrolments compared to its 2023 intake.

title.children: Senate backs bill which would halve international student population at Federation University

image.altText: Paul Cohrs with his hand on the scope of a gun wearing protective ear muffs.

props.synopsis: The Supreme Court of Victoria has heard Paul Cohrs, 64, murdered his mother in north-west Victoria hours after fatally shooting his brother over family business disputes. Â Â

title.children: Former deputy mayor sentenced for shooting his mother with a shotgun over assets dispute

image.altText: Customers line up due to social distancing restrictions outside Bunnings at Oxley in Brisbane's south-west.

props.synopsis: Bunnings is Australia's most trusted brand. But allegations the hardware chain has been abusing its market power have prompted a Senate inquiry, that is set to scrutinise the market power of many large format retailers.

title.children: Concerns suppliers to Bunnings and PetStock won't speak to Senate inquiry for fear of losing contracts

image.altText: Anthony Albanese wears a dark suit, smiles, and shakes hands with Li Qiang who is in a black suit

props.synopsis: It will be his fifth meeting with Li Qiang, and his second in only a few months.

title.children: Anthony Albanese will meet Chinese Premier Li Qiang on the sidelines of ASEAN summit

image.altText: Blake Wilson

props.synopsis: Blake Wilson was killed when a helicopter he was flying crashed into the roof of the hotel on the Cairns Esplanade in August.

title.children: Pilot of helicopter that crashed into roof of Cairns hotel was affected by alcohol, investigation finds

image.altText: 10 or so people searching in rubble for victims.

props.synopsis: Yoav Gallant has warned an Israeli strike on Iran in response to its recent missile attack would be "lethal" and "surprising", as a separate Israeli air strike hit a Lebanese Civil Defense centre in southern Lebanon, killing five members stationed there.Â

title.children: Israeli retaliation against Iran will be 'lethal, precise and surprising,' defence minister says

image.altText: A plume of grey smoke rises from blocks of city apartments at night-time, with lights everywhere

props.synopsis: Israeli air strikes in central and northern Gaza killed 12 people, local authorities said, including nine members of one family.

title.children: Hezbollah claims Israeli troops repelled from southern Lebanon, reports family of nine killed in Gaza air strike

image.altText: Special forces soldier

props.synopsis: Questions are being raised about how alleged war crimes by the Australian Defence Forces are investigated, following the response to the Brereton inquiry.

title.children: Why investigating the alleged war crimes of Australian soldiers is proving so difficult

image.altText: A rickshaw in Bangladesh is cycled through flood waters covering the frame with a passenger in tow.

props.synopsis: A study of scenarios where the world temporarily exceeds 1.5C of warming raises concerns for effects that may not be reversible for decades â or longer.

title.children: Temporarily overshooting 1.5C climate target more damaging than we thought: study

image.altText: Jacob Hersant, dressed in a white shirt and blue suit, photographed in dappled sunlight outdoors.

props.synopsis: A magistrate says Melbourne man Jacob Hersant will be sentenced to jail after being found guilty of performing a Nazi salute last year. He's the first person found guilty of breaking a new Victorian law that bans the salute.

title.children: Melbourne man found guilty of performing Nazi salute to be jailed

image.altText: A woman wearing a dark green hijab and blazer stands in a grass field, serious expression on her face

props.synopsis: Fatima Payman's new political party may not be troubling Labor, but it still has plenty of other headaches to worry about.

title.children: Fatima Payman's big reveal of her new political party has done little to trouble Labor

image.altText: A graphic showing a hand holding a phone. It is superimposed on a drawing of Australia and surrounded by social media apps

props.synopsis: As a social media summit this week discusses the merits of Australia's proposed world-leading ban for teenagers, Ange Lavoipierre asks: why have so few others made it down this path?

title.children: No other government has enforced a total ban for teenagers on social media â so why does Australia think it can?

image.altText: Benjamin Netanyahu and Joe Biden shake hands in the Oval Office.

props.synopsis: Joe Biden and Benjamin Netanyahu have broken nearly two months of silence with a phone call at a tense time in the Middle East â and in their relationship.Â

title.children: After expletive-ridden extracts released, Biden and Netanyahu talk for the first time in months

image.altText: Dreyfus in profile, the reflection of parliament in glass on either side of him.

props.synopsis: Saying that he never wants a repeat of the Robodebt scandal, the attorney-general will introduce laws to oblige public servants to cooperate with investigations, and strengthen ombudsman powers.

title.children: Seeking to prevent another Robodebt scandal, new laws would force public servants to comply with investigations

image.altText: Drone shot of a house missing a roof with debris scattered around it.

props.synopsis: An expanding Hurricane Milton closed in on Florida's west coast on Wednesday, local time, spawning tornadoes and lashing the region with rain and wind hours ahead of its expected landfall near Tampa Bay. Follow live.Â

title.children: Category three storm Hurricane Milton closes in on Florida's west coast

image.altText: A dark-haired woman wearing a black jacket staring directly at the camera

props.synopsis: The ACT Greens defend their vetting process after admitting to knowing about a candidate's blog post comparing September 11 mastermind Osama bin Laden to Jesus Christ.

title.children: ACT Greens vetting process in question after candidate's blog post about terrorist leader Bin Laden surfaced

image.altText: Jason Clare, wearing a suit, stands against a wall.

props.synopsis: A Labor-led Senate inquiry has recommended that a ministerial power to set international student caps at a course level be removed from the governmentâs proposed legislation.

title.children: Ministerial power to set course-level international student caps should be scrapped, Senate committee says

image.altText: A boy stands in a doorway while a police car with flashing lights is parked outside.

props.synopsis: Claire thought that she'd escaped domestic violence after leaving her abusive partner, but she then struggled to find help with the violent meltdowns from her trauma-affected son.

title.children: Claire's son had violent meltdowns so bad she called the police. Here's what she wished she knew then

image.altText: The Rio Tinto building external framed by another building and tree.

props.synopsis: Iron ore giant Rio Tinto has announced it will buy Arcadium Lithium for almost $10 billion in an all cash deal, while the Australian share market has followed Wall Street's lead to trade higher on Thursday. Follow live.

title.children: Rio Tinto snaps up Arcadium Lithium for $9.9b, ASX follows Wall Street higher

Could Google be forced to break up its business?

image.altText: Three young women eating instant noodles with chopsticks.

props.synopsis: Munch on a packet of chips, slurp up a bowl of noodles or tuck into a salami sandwich, and there's a good chance you're also eating monosodium glutamate (MSG). So is it really as bad for us as we're led to believe?

title.children: MSG has been misunderstood for decades. Scientists are now correcting the record

image.altText: Trump greets the crowd as he arrives at a campaign rally.

props.synopsis: The millions of US citizens who live overseas rarely get any attention. In 2024, it's a different story.

title.children: US politicians rarely care about overseas voters. This year is different

image.altText: England batter Joe Root raises his bat and helmet as he walks off the field during a Test match.

props.synopsis: Joe Root is now England's most prolific Test run-scorer, surpassing Alastair Cook in Pakistan, and he has time on his side to go for Sachin Tendulkar's overall record.

title.children: 'Genius' Joe Root becomes England's greatest run-scorer with plenty of time to chase down Tendulkar

image.altText: Kevin McCloud stands underneath the Sydney Harbour Bridge. His hands are in his pockets and a green kombi van is behind him

props.synopsis: The host of the popular UK lifestyle show says he's grateful for the people willing to let cameras behind the scenes â "sometimes mistakenly" â while they push the boundaries on what's possible in design.

title.children: Grand Designs' Kevin McCloud says 'nuttiness' of the show's chaotic projects is the best part

image.altText: A woman in a colourful jumper and black headscarf singing into her phone.

props.synopsis: Most of us donât have perfect pitch, so we canât name the sounds we hear. But research shows our memory for pitch is better than we think, and earworms have a lot to do with the reason why.

title.children: Earworms can be annoying. But they can also help you sing solo

image.altText: Albanese NBN composite

props.synopsis: The federal government is convinced its move to ban the privatisation of the NBN Co is a winner, but will voters care?

title.children: Under pressure over the Middle East, Labor is answering questions nobody asked

image.altText: Comedian Sashi Perera leans into her husband, both are smiling and posing beside a colourful wall on a street.

props.synopsis: This year, my husband and I decided to stop IVF. Life doesn't look like what we planned but it's so much more than enough.

title.children: 'Finally time for sadness and rest': Life after stopping IVF

image.altText: Poppy wears a black jumper and has her face blurred as she stands in front of microphones in a park on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: Poppy, 20, was visiting Australia for the first time when she was punched by a man during an altercation in Richmond last month.

title.children: Man being questioned by police after altercation left a tourist with a broken jaw in Melbourne

image.altText: Chief Maycon, an Indigenous Krenak leader (left), is fighting a court battle against BHP

props.synopsis: Nineteen people died and vast swathes of land and waterways were damaged when BHP and local mining company Vale's tailing dam collapsed in 2015. Now, First Nations and traditional Brazilian people are lobbying ahead of aÂ major class action.Â

title.children: 'Mining companies killed our god': Brazilian Indigenous people explain why they're suing BHP for $70 billion

image.altText: Ken McCallum

props.synopsis: MI5 director general Ken McCallum says Britain is experiencing a staggering rise in assassination attempts and other crimes by Russia and Iran.Â

title.children: Britain's intelligence agency says Russia is trying to create 'mayhem' in the UK
